comment_text:
Since Elon responds to your tweets, you might want to ask him if it really made sense to attempt multiple static fires especially since that led to damage to two of the Raptor engines and subsequent static fire attempts, after the engine replacement, had to be aborted.
It just seems that those multiple static fires was an ad hoc decision that had led to delays in launching of SN9 and testing those key concepts needed for further Starship development.
so boring, land it on the moon or mars and return, that would be exciting, but this, not so much

Thank you so much for making these videos, Tim.
As much as I'm a space flight enthusiast, as little time I have for spending 5.5 hours watching a livestream to see little less than 15 combined seconds of "action".
I appreciate your efforts to edit and provide those "Best moments" cut.
can someone eli5 why they are doing this?
i am really curious, if the working of this raptors can produce so much damaging debris from the ground, how will SpaceX avoid the damaging of the large vacuum nozzles.

It's really cool to have slowmo @120fps, but these YT vids are still only playing back at 30fps.  Talking head style vids are fine at 30 I think, but anything demonstrating motion, especially something fleeting like these static fire tests, would greatly benefit from 60fps render and upload.  Just a suggestion, thanks for making the awesome vids!  :)
